did.unittitle: Dick Thornburgh Papers, Series XVII. Ongoing Career
did.abstract: In May 1993 Dick Thornburgh returned to Washington, rejoining Kirkpatrick & Lockhart as counsel in their Washington office. That role has enabled Thornburgh to devote time to clients, and yet retain the opportunity to pursue outside interests and challenges which have been many and varied. For example, his foreign trips include visits to Taiwan, Russia, and several to Hong Kong, regarding the rule of law. Trips to Guatemala (regarding governmental corruption), to Nigeria (regarding federalism, interstate relations and other governance issues), and to Buenos Aires (on fighting corruption) are also well documented. Other trips abroad concern his continued dedication to the rights of persons with disabilities. Major challenges include, for example, his appointment as Examiner in the WorldCom bankruptcy proceedings, the largest ever filed, and his choice in 2004 by CBS to conduct an investigation into the "60 Minutes Wednesday" segment on President Bush's service in the Texas Air National Guard. During the 1990s he embarked upon a new mini-career on television as a legal commentator on subjects such as the O.J. Simpson case, and President Clinton issues. One constructive by-product of the horrific September 11 attacks on the World Trade Towers was a review for the National Academy of Public Administration of FBI plans for reorganization, a task force that Thornburgh was asked to chair, and additional service as a member of the FBI Director's Advisory Board. Digital reproductions of portions of the collection are available online.

processinfo.p: This collection was processed by Nancy Watson, Curator of the Thornburgh Papers, Holly Mengel, Project Archivist, and a team of graduate students. Processing was made possible by a grant from the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania in 2002.

Revision and rearrangement for the encoded version of the finding aid provided by Holly Mengel in 2004. Information about the collection title and the controlled access terms was extracted from the MARC record in the University of Pittsburgh catalog Voyager ID number: 3608599

did.unittitle: Ongoing Career

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Following his sojourn at the United Nations, at the end of February 1993, Dick Thornburgh returned to Washington, his twenty-five year career in public office at an end, and ready for what he termed a role as "useful citizen."

The quest of a new baseball commissioner came his way in May 1993, and friends who knew of his long-standing love of baseball encouraged his interest. Although he survived several cuts, his final contribution to the matter was an op-ed piece in the Wall Street Journal, in August 1994. Meanwhile, after scrutiny of alternatives, he decided to return, once again, to Kirkpatrick & Lockhart as counsel in their Washington Office. That role has enabled Thornburgh to devote over half his time to clients, and yet retain the opportunity to pursue other outside interests developed over the years.

These interests have been many and varied, most of which are well documented in these files and frequently draw on Thornburgh's previous experience, both in government generally and at the United Nations in particular. A major topic, for example, has been the rule of law in developing countries and others emerging from Soviet domination. "If these nations were to see more democracy, respect for human rights and market-oriented economies ... the rule of law was an absolute sine qua non. Without it, free elections, corruption-free government and due process would be impossible ... Thus I became a veritable missionary for the rule of law" (Evidence, p. 336).

The section here on foreign trips includes visits to Taiwan, Russia, and several to Hong Kong, all regarding the rule of law. Other trips to Guatemala (regarding governmental corruption), to Nigeria (regarding federalism, interstate relations and other governance issues), to Buenos Aires (on fighting corruption), are well documented here as well. In addition, other trips abroad concern his continued dedication to the rights of persons with disabilities, particularly in a return trip to Korea where Thornburgh and his wife, Ginny, discussed issues of religion and disability. "Our visit left us feeling that Korea had a long way to go in affording dignity to its citizens with disability, but we were heartened that so many people of goodwill, particularly within the religious communities, were trying to meet those challenges" (Evidence, p. 346).

Other challenges presented themselves, for example, examination of World Bank's "mechanisms to deal with fraud and corruption connected with its lending" (Evidence, p. 347), and involvement with civil justice reform, growing out of a report on the subject prepared by the Department of Justice in 1991 for the President's Council on Competitiveness. Thornburgh's interest in science and technology which dated back to the Ben Franklin Partnership of Governor days further took center stage from early to mid 1990s, and concern about product liability and caps on punitive damages are well expressed in his op-eds on the subject, all of which are available here online.

Also, during the 1990s, he "embarked upon a new mini-career as a television 'personality' ... The first call came on July 6, 1994, from the producer of Larry King Live, asking if [he] would consider a guest appearance that night to discuss some of the legal issues in the O.J. Simpson case ... One television appearance led to others; in total [he] appeared forty-five times on CNN to examine various aspects of the Simpson case" (Evidence, p. 352). This led to further television appearances in connection with high-profile cases such as: murders of JonBenet Ramsey and Chandra Levy, President Clinton's "misadventures" (Evidence, p. 353), and other appearances to discuss varying legal issues, over many years, on CNN's Late Edition, hosted by Wolf Blitzer. "Despite the sometimes long hours of preparation required to present accurate and well-informed views ... I must acknowledge that the whole process of offering views on matters of concern to the nation via the talk show circuit was most satisfying. It obliged me to keep on top of a variety of developments, and it was quite fulfilling to be asked my opinion on the issues of the day" (Evidence, p. 357). Many of these appearances with Thornburgh's handwritten notes in preparation are represented in these files and are particularly intriguing.

Throughout these years Thornburgh has spoken around the country, frequently including a plea for involvement in public life. What Thornburgh describes as his most comprehensive review of this subject is the Webb Lecture to the National Academy of Public Administration (NAPA) in November 1998, which is available here online. To this group he stated: "Democracy is not a spectator sport. All of us must exercise the opportunity to contribute to improving and sustaining higher levels of performance in public life.

In the fall of 2002, Thornburgh was appointed examiner in WorldCom bankruptcy, the largest in American history, resulting from nearly $11 billion misreported revenues and expenditures. The archive includes extensive documentation of this "massive task" and all three reports.

The files in this ongoing section of Dick Thornburgh's career are in the following subseries: 1) Speeches and Testimony; 2) Transcripts; 3) Foreign Trips; 4) Events; 5) Professional and Civic Work; 6) Media Interviews; 7) Correspondence; 8) Articles and Issues; 9) Where the Evidence Leads; 10) Varied Subjects of Interest; 11) Three Mile Island; and 12) Awards and Honors.
As Thornburgh continues his career more files are contributed to his archives ongoing. Stay tuned.

did.unittitle: Speeches and Testimony

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thornburgh's ongoing career, for archive purposes, began March 1993, just after his sojourn at the United Nations. Since that time, up to and including April 2004 there were over 100 speeches and testimonies which have been digitized and are available here online. In 2013 an additional 127 were added.

In some respects, there is no better way to recognize the diversity and substance of Thornburgh's career than in reviewing these speeches and testimonies. There is a remarkably broad array of topics which relate to his many ongoing interests and commitments, for example: human rights, drug and alcohol abuse, business crime, rule of law, partnerships in science and technology, law enforcement, United Nations, merit selection for judges, civil justice reform, health care, Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA), war against terrorism, disability and civil rights, Three Mile Island, crises in corporate America, WorldCom bankruptcy, and World Bank investigation. These were delivered, just for example, before Committees of Congress, at Graduations, at the Vatican Conference on Drug and Alcohol Abuse, to colleges and universities, bar associations, Chambers of Commerce and United Nations events.

did.unittitle: Transcripts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: There are over 70 transcripts in this section that exhibit similar diversity as of the speeches and testimonies in Thornburgh's ongoing career. Most of these transcripts are from television appearances when Thornburgh was invited to discuss various timely and controversial issues in the headlines. Primarily the transcripts are from program appearances such as: MacNeil/Lehrer NewsHour, CNN "Late Edition" with Wolf Blitzer, and "Larry King Live." Others include: CNN's "Early Edition," "World Today," "Judy Woodruff Inside Politics," and ABC's "Ron Owens Program" and more.

Topics include, for example: President Clinton's legal troubles, the controversial year 2000 election, tax cuts, FBI leadership, sniper murder case, Pledge of Allegiance decision, 9/11 terrorism, the Patriot Act, Three Mile Island (TMI), CIA Leak, and Supreme Court matters and appointees. Some additional transcripts are from Congressional Subcommittees.

Transcript of interview with Dick Thornburgh : Career update
Foreign Trips

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: There are eighteen foreign trips in this section of Thornburgh's ongoing career. These clearly derive from Thornburgh's outstanding career and the esteem with which he is regarded.

The majority of the foreign trips were organized to monitor the elections in newly democratic countries, such as Ukraine, Russia, Nigeria, Hong Kong, and Cambodia. These trips were organized primarily by two organizations-the International Republican Institute (IRI) and the National Democratic Institute (NDI). The mission of both is similar and well summarized in the mission statement found on the IRI website: a "dedicat[ion] to advancing democracy, freedom, self-government and the rule of law worldwide." Thornburgh's personal commitment to the promotion of democracy and Rule of Law worldwide are clearly represented in the election and pre-election observation missions, the "Good Governance" conferences in Guatemala, and the Rule of Law mission to Russia.

There are several other trips where Thornburgh was invited to be a featured speaker. These include his trip to Lisbon, Portugal, to participate in the USIA U.S. Speakers Program, and his trip with Ginny on the Radisson Seven Seas Cruise Tour of Brazil, during which he was the featured "celebrity speaker."

Dick and Ginny Thornburgh's exceptional commitment to disability issues also relate to two trips in particular, both sponsored by the Education and Rehabilitation Exchange Foundation (EREF). Both of these trips were to the Republic of Korea (South Korea). These demonstrate the couple's unwavering commitment to advocating and improving the conditions and treatment of disabled persons worldwide. Especially meaningful is a reprint of an article, included in the files, written by Ginny Thornburgh and published in Guideposts magazine, entitled, "For the Love of Peter."

The Thornburghs also enjoyed two trips sponsored by the Princeton Theological Seminary (PTS), for which Ginny serves as a member of the Board of Trustees. In 2000, Ginny asked Dick on the PTS information sheet regarding the Holy Land-Jerusalem trip if they could go for her 60th birthday, which they did. Three years later, she reciprocated with an encircled paragraph on the French Reformation trip in the PTS newsletter wishing her husband "Happy birthday!" The material for these trips is mostly "touristy" and reflects their personal enjoyment.

The foreign trip files are organized by destination, with the countries most visited (Russia, Hong Kong, Korea) first, and all singular trips to countries following. The reasoning for a non-chronological order for the trips derives from Thornburgh's inevitable in-depth preparation prior to and subsequent to visiting a country. This is particularly significant when he had occasion to visit a country more than once. For example, Thornburgh visited Russia in 1993, 1995, and 1996. Yet he monitored and collected news clippings and articles each year from 1991-1997. For that reason, all the Russia trip files appear first, with a subsequent "news clippings" and "publications and journals" section. The "single-visit" trips are arranged in chronological order.

The Ongoing Career foreign trips and related files are arranged as follows: 1) International Republican Institute (IRI) Russian Election Monitoring Mission, December 7-15, 1993; 2) Trip to Russia, October 24, 1995; 3) International Republican Institute (IRI) Russian Election Monitoring Mission, June 10-18, 1996; 4) Russia news clippings and articles (from all trips); 5) Publications and journals regarding Russia (from all trips); 6) International Republican Institute (IRI) Rule of Law Mission to Hong Kong, June 12-19, 1994; 7) National Democratic Institute (NDI) Pre-election Mission to Hong Kong, March 15-18, 1998; 8) Trip to Hong Kong, January 10-16, 1999; 9) Hong Kong news clippings and articles (from all trips); 10) Publications and journals regarding Hong Kong (from all trips); 11) "That All May Worship," Education and Rehabilitation Exchange Foundation (EREF) trip of Ginny and Dick Thornburgh to the Republic of Korea, June 12-19, 1995; 12) Education and Rehabilitation Exchange Foundation (EREF) disability-related trip of Ginny and Dick Thornburgh to the Republic of Korea, July 12-20, 1998; 13) Korea news clippings and articles (from both trips); 14) Publications and journals regarding Korea (from both trips); 15) USIA "U.S. Speakers Program," Lisbon, Portugal, March 28-31, 1993; 16) Publications regarding Portugal; 17) Trip of Dick and Ginny Thornburgh to Taiwan, August 22-30, 1993; 18) International Republican Institute (IRI) and Institute of Democracy and Development (IDE) delegation to the "Good Governance Conference," November 28-30, 1994 and the "Second Good Governance Conference," Guatemala, February 2-3, 1995; 19) Guatemala news clippings and articles; 20) Publications and journals regarding Guatemala; 21) National Democratic Institute (NDI) "Nigeria Governors' Forum," Nigeria, April 26-29, 1999; 22) Nigeria news clippings and articles; 23) International Republican Institute (IRI) Presidential Election Observation Mission to Ukraine, November 9-17, 1999; 24) News clippings and articles regarding Ukraine; 25) Princeton Theological Seminary (PTS) Tour to the Holy Land, Jerusalem, trip of Ginny and Dick Thornburgh, March 26-April 6, 2000; 26) News clippings and articles regarding Jerusalem; 27) Books and publications regarding The Holy Land (Jerusalem); 28) Radisson Seven Seas Cruises, trip of Ginny and Dick Thornburgh from Rio de Janeiro to Fortaleza, Brazil, April 20-26, 2002; 29) Council for the United States and Italy Workshop, trip to Italy, June 7-8, 2002; 30) National Democratic Institute (NDI) Pre-election Mission to Cambodia, January 27-February 4, 2003; 31) News clippings and articles regarding Cambodia; 32) Princeton Theological Seminary (PTS) [French] Reformation Tour of France and Switzerland, trip of Ginny and Dick Thornburgh, April 22-May 5, 2003.

China and Human Rights Issue

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: This issue did not involve a trip to China, although Thornburgh did request that China permit him to come. His commitment over several years to this issue was significant and important. Liu Xiaobo was imprisoned largely due to the authorities' suspicion that he was an organizer of Charter O8, a declaration that outlines a vision for a more democratic China. Ultimately Liu was sentenced to prison for 10 years despite the significant efforts of notable lawyers and political figures in US, such as Dick Thornburgh.

Hong Kong

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Thornburgh spent considerable time participating in events for the Committee for Hong Kong, a bipartisan organization devoted to supporting democracy, the rule of law, and other promises made to Hong Kong by China in the agreement governing Hong Kong's return to China 1997. Also in Thornburgh's files are three separate and important trips to Hong Kong: June 12-19, 1994; March 15-18, 1998, and January 10-16, 1999. Much material here interacts with and is related to those trips.

Events

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thornburgh continues to be a regular participant in many organizations' functions, committees of the Congress, dinners, seminars, meetings, dedications and commencements, for example. In this portion of the collection the researcher will find the speeches he gave at the many different speaking engagements, and interviews with a variety of interviewers ranging from the student writing an article to national media. Thornburgh continues to focus upon his strong interests and commitments, which are evident in the events, particularly white-collar crime, testimony given on the subject of terrorism, narcotics and foreign relations, and the American Disabilities Act (ADA) to name a few. This section is arranged in chronological order by date of event.

There is a second group of events that are grouped by year. There are several events within each year, primarily those for which there is only a minimal amount of information. However, though the information is slim, there are several interesting topics and events, which took place between 1993-2002. Included are the official presentations of portraits for Mr. Thornburgh, President George H.W. Bush, and Barbara Bush.
Lastly are schedules from his work at his law firm, Kirkpatrick and Lockhart.

Professional and Civic Work

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Thornburgh continues to participate in and lead numerous professional and civic undertakings. The first for which files were available are as follows: Henry J. Stimson Center (Board of Directors); Allegheny County Home Rule Committee (Honorary Chairman); National Academy of Public Administration, Chair (NAPA); Legal Policy Advisory Board of the Washington Legal Foundation (Chairman); Task Force on the Future of Shared State and Federal Securities Regulation; U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission's proceedings against John G. Black, Devon Capital Management Services, Inc. and Financial Management Sciences, Inc.; and "A Republican Case for United Nations Funding," project of the Emergency Coalition for U.S. Financial Support of the United Nations.

Subsequent files added to the collection in 2013 are: Internet Child Pornography, World Bank, Inter-American Development Bank, WorldCom Bankruptcy, Ethics, Dan Rather "60 Minutes Wednesday," Board of Science Applications Investigation of Greek Contract Issues, Russian Federation vs Bank of New York, Freeh Report regarding Paterno, FBI Transformation Panel, FBI Director's Advisory Board, Gettysburg Foundation Board, Terrorism Task Force, and Attorney-Client Privilege.

The above additions in 2013 vary in extent of documentation from a simple report or statement to files that cover many years as a task force leader. The variety of subject matter and responsibility well represent Thornburgh's continuing legal and political acumen and high regard.

Internet Child Pornography

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: While Attorney General Thornburgh worked hard for the passage of the Child Protection and Obscenity Enforcement Act of 1988 and set forth Justice Department priorities to vigorously prosecute child pornography and obscenity by specialists in each U.S. attorney's office and a national effort against producers and distributors of illegal hard-core videos. In 2002 he chaired the National Research Council committee on how to deal with the explosion of inappropriate sexually explicit material available to young people on the Internet. The resulting report was described by the New York Times as "one of the most thorough…on protecting children from Internet pornography" although it pointed out the absence of a "quick fix."

World Bank

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: In 1999, World Bank President Jim Wolfensohn asked Thornburgh to examine the bank's mechanisms to deal with fraud and corruption connected to its lending. Estimates that as much as 25 percent of its funding found its way into pockets of corrupt officials eventually were recognized by the bank as a great concern rather than merely "political" reality. Thornburgh with the help of some former associates from the Department of Justice and the United Nations learned about the culture of the bank and figured out methods to address the problem. The resulting report delivered in early 2000 recommended a new Office of Institutional Integrity which was up and running within months. They continued to act as consultants to the bank on the implementation of the recommendations.

WorldCom Bankruptcy

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: In August 2002, the U.S. Bankruptcy Court in the Southern District of New York appointed Thornburgh the examiner in the case filed by WorldCom, one of the world's largest telecommunications companies. This was a "sorry tale of corporate wrongdoing" (Evidence, p. 362). Thornburgh put together a team, with whom to undertake what he described a "massive task." "My job was to carry out an independent investigation into what happened in the WorldCom matter and to assure Bankruptcy Judge Arthur Gonzales that procedures and persons involved in any past wrongdoing were not carried forward into any reorganized entity… and finally to make recommendations to aid in avoiding repetition elsewhere of the acts that caused the downfall of WorldCom" (Evidence, p. 363). The three committee reports over several years place major responsibility for WorldCom's collapse on the members of the board of directors, especially those who served on its audit and compensation committees. Major officials involved in the fraud were convicted in federal court.

Ethics

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: WorldCom and other corporate debacles and wrongdoing that were subsequently uncovered produced many legislative and regulatory responses. These included the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 and other regulations to avoid similar instances of corporate corruption. This section relates to relationships between corporations and their lawyers, and responsibilities, compensation, and liabilities of boards of directors. Thornburgh ultimately concluded that ethical conduct of corporate affairs would make more difference than all the laws and regulations and spoke often and wrote articles to this effect. The files date between 2003 and 2006.

Dan Rather "60 Minutes Wednesday"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Not long after the WorldCom matter was completed, Thornburgh was called by CBS News President Andrew Heyward, on September 21, 2004. He asked if Thornburgh would undertake an independent investigation with Associated Press CEO Lou Boccardi into preparation of the September 8 broadcast relating to the Texas Air National Guard Service of President George W. Bush, and public statements by CBS News following and defending the segment. This was extremely sensitive due to the proximity of the 2004 presidential election so work began immediately. The investigation revealed serious shortcomings. Ultimately Dan Rather relinquished his anchor position on the CBS Evening News and Mary Mapes and other senior individuals were terminated and/or resigned. Ultimately CBS News adopted all the recommendations in the final report which had received much public and news attention.

Russian Federation vs. Bank of New York

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: A bizarre case involving U.S. Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations (RICO) statute took Thornburgh to the legal scene in the Russian Federation in 2008. In May 2007 a civil case was initiated in Moscow against Bank of New York Mellon. The complaint sought damages of $22.5 billion from the bank under the U.S. RICO statue. The bank's defense counsel engaged a number of experts in U.S. law to testify on its behalf, including Thornburgh, who went to Moscow and did testify, a copy of which is included here.

scopecontent.p: Thornburgh was asked by the Paterno family to perform an independent and objective review of the "Freeh Report" regarding the University's response to child abuse charges and its references to Paterno. The ensuing report entitled "Review of the Freeh Report Concerning Joseph Paterno" is dated February 6, 2013 and describes the Freeh Report as seriously flawed.

FBI Transformation Panel

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: One of the constructive by-products of the dreadful 9/11 attacks was a top-to-bottom review of law enforcement and intelligence agencies, which included the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Thornburgh chaired this major review at the request of the National Academy of Public Administration (NAPA) of FBI's Director Bob Mueller's plans to make necessary improvements in the Bureau's processes and practices. This was an active and detailed process that extended from 2006-2010. There were several reports and multiple testimonies involved and are included here.

FBI Director's Advisory Board

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The FBI Transformation Panel reports were generally positive about Mueller's plan to modernize and update the FBI. Mueller asked Thornburgh in August 2005 to serve on the FBI Director's Advisory Board which had been authorized by Congress in February 2003 to independently advise the Director on matters relating to science, technology, research and other matters of special interest to the FBI. Also the transformation panel recommendations were seen as critical to put in place. Thornburgh served on the board 2005-2011.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Thornburgh was asked to be a member of the Terrorism Task Force in October 2001. The purposes were to identify issues where careful thought is required and that occur in early days of a great crisis. Major issues for the task force were to relate to an International/National Agenda, Homeland Security, and US & World Economy. Thornburgh was a member briefly October 2001 into fall 2002, when other significant challenges for him ensued.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Thornburgh was appointed by the American Bar Association to the Task Force on Attorney-Client Privilege in 2006. The files extend to August 2010 at the time of the Final Report. They include meeting agendas and minutes, Congressional testimony, and other background information. This subject was said to concern "grave dangers" to attorney-client privilege which is described as a fundamental element of the American system of justice.

did.unittitle: Urban Institute

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: The Urban Institute is a non-profit research organization in Washington, D.C. Thornburgh became the Co-Chairman of the Institute's Policy Advisory Group in 1996. This group worked specifically and extensively on a major new initiative, "Assessing New Federalism." This focused on implementation at the state and local levels of policies and actions regarding services and outcomes for children, families and communities. Thornburgh continued participation as an active Trustee on this and other matters into 2006 . and was awarded Life Trustee status.

Science, Technology and Economic Development

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Thornburgh's interest in science and technology contributing to economic development was initiated in the establishment of the Ben Franklin Partnership while Governor of Pennsylvania (1979-1987). It became a national model for Government-Industry-University cooperation in technology transfer. In September 1993 former Ohio Governor Dick Celeste and Thornburgh co-chaired a colloquium to establish federal-state cooperation in science and technology, which was attended by representatives of all 50 states plus relevant federal agencies. They subsequently co-chaired a twenty member State-Federal Task Force on Science and Technology in 1995 to make recommendations on structuring and implementing a partnership effort. Thornburgh travelled across the country to promote the concepts and conclusions in the report. Later Thornburgh chaired a study commissioned by the National Research Council, travelling widely to promote support for its recommendations. With the ongoing financial support of the Carnegie Corporation a non-profit State Science and Technology Institute was ultimately established. Thornburgh became its first Board Chairman and served until the end of 2002. There are extensive files here on this subject.

Local Government Reform

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Dick Thornburgh interacted with Pittsburgh and Allegheny County concerns beginning with the 1967-8 Pennsylvania Constitutional Convention, as one of the elected delegates. There was much interest at that time in concepts of home rule and more streamlined local government. Ever since Thornburgh has spoken about and has been concerned with the future of Pittsburgh and Allegheny County. In the 21st century he continued to support and encourage community civic groups and leaders committed to furthering progressive goals in speeches, local committees, and meetings.

Civil Justice Reform, Tort Reform

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Thornburgh's interest in this subject derived in part from his participation while Attorney General in the Council on Competitiveness report (available here): Agenda for Civil Justice Reform in America, August 1991. Several widely publicized cases revived public interest in problems associated with lawsuit abuse. Thornburgh made many appearances on behalf of Civil Justice Reform Groups in the next several years. A number of states enacted tort reform, including Ohio and California where Thornburgh had put major effort for the Civil Justice Reform Group. As Chairman of the Washington Legal Foundation Policy Board there was additional support of tort reform for years ongoing.

National Museum of Industrial History

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Thornburgh served on the original Board of Directors of the National Museum of Industrial History, beginning January 1999. The Museum is affiliated with the Smithsonian Institution and is viewed as the premier museum of industrial history in the U.S. It is dedicated to preserving the story and accomplishments of American industry and is our country's largest brownfield project, on the site of the former Bethlehem Steel corporation plant, in Bethlehem, PA. After some funding and leadership delays it is scheduled to open Summer 2016.

Media Interviews and Background Information

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: During the years following Thornburgh's work at the United Nations, he "embarked upon a new mini-career as a television 'personality'" (Evidence, p.352). Thornburgh, of course, as a political figure, had much experience appearing as guest on network news shows, but the 1990s explosion of twenty-four-hour-a-day news networks, such as FOX News, CNN, CNBC, etc., drastically increased the news shows and their coverage.

He first received a phone call from the producer of CNN's "Larry King Live" show on July 6, 1994, requesting Thornburgh to appear on the show to discuss some of the legal implications of the O.J. Simpson case, which was already promising to become a huge media blitz of both analysis and hype over the next year and a half, until a verdict would be reached. Thornburgh writes, "I was about to become engrossed in 'the trial of the century'" (Evidence, p.352). Thornburgh and two others became "regulars" regarding the trial, Thornburgh consistently interpreting the actual legal issues involved. Thornburgh had occasion during the months of the trial to advocate and argue for several improvements to the criminal justice system, including the "removal of racist policemen like Mark Fuhrman from police forces across America; closer scrutiny by prosecutors on the background of all witnesses ... judicial appointment of scientific experts to replace highly paid, partisan 'hired guns' engaged in scientific swearing contests; restrictions on the number of lawyers permitted to participate on either side" (Evidence, p.352) and other issues. Thornburgh also dealt with the hot debate topic of camera surveillance in courtrooms, but found himself in the minority of those in favor, noting Judge Lance Ito's courtroom during the trial little different that the venues in which Thornburgh had tried cases-"Barely perceptible cameras unobtrusively recorded the proceedings" (Evidence, p.353).

His successful, and highly regarded appearances on CNN resulted in a number of opportunities to host the show after the Simpson trial, when King took the night off. These gave him an opportunity to examine legal aspects of other high-profile criminal cases such as Gotti and the Unabomber, as well as varied topics such as elections, DNA evidence and wrongful convictions, Bosnia and Ireland, and gubernatorial issues of economic development and welfare reform. Thornburgh also appeared on other shows, such as CNN's "Burden of Proof" and CNN's "Late Edition," hosted by Wolf Blitzer.

These files are organized as follows: 1) Thornburgh's show appearances on CNN's "Larry King Live," as host as well as panelist. These files include Ginny Thornburgh's notes, Thornburgh's notes in preparation, and some post-analysis, and background research; 2) Thornburgh's show appearances on other CNN programs; 3) Thornburgh's files on the O.J. Simpson case, including notes, correspondence, materials relating to Thornburgh's "Larry King Live" appearances and work, and other files of Thornburgh on the case; 4) Newswires, clippings, and journal articles regarding O.J. Simpson and related cases.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Included here is general correspondence both to and from Dick Thornburgh, 1992-2000. There is correspondence to and from government leaders, world leaders, and the general public. Included are two personal letters from President George H.W. Bush, one regarding the UN and the other a response to Thornburgh's letter with congratulations upon the election of Bush's son, George, in 1998.

Articles and Issues

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The articles and news clippings here reflect the attention given to Dick Thornburgh's ongoing career, with Kirkpatrick & Lockhart, and also working with a number of public policy organizations, just for example. His advice was sought by World Bank and governmental officials in developing nations, and others. Some of these articles and files relate to the WorldCom investigation and bankruptcy, pornography, terrorism, disability matters, and civil justice reform, and also regarding Ginny Thornburgh and her ongoing work in the disability field. They reflect the multi-dimensional aspects of Thornburgh's continuing career and counsel sought from him on major topics of the day, as well as even the prospect of becoming Baseball Commissioner.

An additional section, added in 2013, pertains to President Clinton's "misadventures," particularly confusing legal matters relating to the issue of Independent Counsel. There is other information on this subject in the Media Interviews subseries.

did.unittitle: Law Suits re: US Senate 1991 Campaign

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Notes
scopecontent.p: Following Thornburgh's unsuccessful Campaign for US Senate in 1991 law suits were initiated by two creditors, Carl Rove and Optima Direct Inc., regarding campaign debts incurred close to election day for "get out the vote" efforts. Attempts to raise further funds at that time were hampered, among other things, by Thornburgh's almost immediate appointment to the United Nations, which prohibited political fund-raising. Ultimately the Thornburgh's were obliged to cover the shortfall with their own personal funds.
